place.desc: Gladys Stephens attends the 1909 Seattle World's Fair and John J. Macintyre is in Seattle in early October 1909.
In her letter of 9 July 1909, Gladys Stephens anticipates visiting Puget Sound.
The Hotel Georgian was built in 1908 and had seven floors and 108 rooms. It was demolished in 1971.
Gladys stayed at the Hotel Georgian during her visit to Seattle in August of 1909. It seems that she made repeated visits to the Georgian both before and after her excursion to Alaska.
Gladys Stephens mentions a correspondence occurring in Boston
Gladys Stephens reminisces about her time in Mexico.
In her letter dated August 8, 1909, Gladys tells her mother about plans for an upcoming excursion to Mexico.
Gladys Stephens mentions as a site of a known house
Gladys Stephens notes an acquaintance residing in Maine
Gladys has visited California recently

In her letter dated August 8, 1909, Gladys mentions meeting a wealthy judge who owns a large ranch in Texas. It is also clear that this judge is an acquaintance of Gladys's Uncle Alex. She has been invited to visit them, although the exact location of their ranch within the state of Texas is not specified.
Gladys lives in El Paso.
The Northwestern picks up a cannery crew in Klawock.
John J. Macintyre writes to Gladys about the totems of Tuxekan, a Tlingit village.
John J. Macintyre stops briefly in Ketchikan and spends some time with Irene Palmer.
John J. Macintyre recounts an accident involving an automobile coming from Georgetown.

In his letter of 04 October 1909, John J. Macintyre recounts an accident involving an electric street car derailing at the entrance to the Alaska-Yukon Pacific Exposition, which later became the campus for the University of Washington.
Mrs. A. T. Stephens lives in Newton.
Cora L. Anderson writes to Mrs. A.T. Stephens from Sherborn.
Cora mentions that Gladys sent her a letter from Colorado
Gladys sends her mother a picture taken in San Diego.
John J. Macintyre addresses his 8-13-1909 letter to Gladys Stephens in San Francisco, and the letter mentions it as the next location on her trip.
Gladys spends some time in Los Angeles before leaving to El Paso.
John J. Macintyre mentions that he will travel to Valdez in his 8-23-1909 letter to Gladys Stephens.
In his 8-23-1909 letter to Gladys Stephens, John J. Macintyre mentions that he and his crew are looking for Cape St. Elias.
In his 8-23-1909 letter to Gladys Stephens, John J. Macintyre mentions that he will shortly be arriving in Juneau.

In her letters of July 6 and 10, 1909, Stephens refers to a three-day trip through Yellowstone National Park on her way to Seattle.
In her letter dated August 8, 1909, Gladys Stephens mentions having sent postcards from Yellowstone to her Aunt, which she likely purchased on her three-day excursion prior to returning to Seattle.

item.desc: Launched as the John S. Kimball in 1900, later renamed James Dollar and later Santa Clara. Ran aground on 2 November 1915 in Coos Bay, Oregon.

state.desc: John J. Macintyre sails on and uses stationery from the S.S. Northwestern, which was acquired by the Alaska Steamship Company when it merged with the Northwest (Northern) Steamship Company in 1909. Based in Seattle, the Alaska Steamship Company was founded in 1895 and disbanded in 1971.

tagsDecl.rendition: text written on an approximately 45-degree angle to the surrounding line(s) of text, slanting downward left to right

projectDesc.p: This edition is the latest in a series of collaboratively produced electronic editions of previously unpublished nineteenth-century American manuscripts held in the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University. Previous editions include "My Dear Elizabeth," five letters written by Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to her sister Elizabeth Palmer Peabody between ca. 1837 and 1868 (currently being revised), "Dear Wife," twenty-one letters written by riverboat captain William B. Anderson to his wife Louisa while he plied the Ohio river during the height of the American Civil War, 1862–1864, and "Journal of a Tour to Europe," by Samuel Sullivan Cox. These documentary editions are intended to provide wide exposure and access to manuscripts that might otherwise be difficult for scholars to discover and consult, and to provide users with a variety of tools for studying those texts.

Each text was edited in connection with a graduate course offered by H. Lewis Ulman, Associate Professor of English at The Ohio State University. The courses aim to provide students with an opportunity to explore issues of textuality and mediation that arise when our cultural archives spread from page to screen and from library shelves to networked databases. Electronic textual editing is our vehicle for examining what happens—and envisioning what might happen—when artifacts in one medium are represented in another medium, especially with regard to the interpretive work of reading. Electronic textual editions also provide a contact zone that can help us reflect on what manuscript, print, and "born digital" artifacts can tell us about their unique properties and their relationships to one another.

While providing a reliable textual edition is a sine qua non, the Doane edition also explores ways of telling four stories inextricably woven into our work: the lives and historical milieu evoked by the texts, the history of the physical journal (including its recent restoration), the editorial process that gave rise to this particular interpretation of the text, and the mediation of our electronic delivery system.

editorialDecl.p: Scanning. The manuscript pages were scanned as 24-bit TIFF images at 400 dots per inch (dpi), then coverted to 8-bit JPEG images at 400 dpi and full quality before being loaded into an image server that provides zoomable views of the production images. All edges of manuscript pages were overscanned by at least 1/4 inch. No color correction was used at any stage of image preparation, but a scan of a photographer's 18% grey card on the same scanner produced RGB values at the center of 91/95/107 after applying a 150% Gaussian Blur in Adobe Photoshop to average color values. Thus, a properly configured monitor should provide a reasonable approximation of colors on the manuscript pages.

Production Location of Digital Assets. The TEI XML-compliant transcription of the Doane journal, along with five XSL style sheets used to provide variant "views" of the edition, are stored on a server hosted by College of Arts and Sciences at The Ohio State University. High resolution scans of the manuscript pages, scans of plates from contemporary sources, and photographs of the journal are stored in the Media Manager application hosted by the College of Arts and Science at The Ohio State University. The files constituting the project's Web site are stored on a Web server hosted by the College.
Archiving of Digital Assets. Once the edition is complete, its digital assets will be archived in The Ohio State University https://kb.osu.edu/dspace/index.jsp Knowledge Bank.

refsDecl.p: Markup of Physical Structure and Page Layout. The manuscript pages, encoded by the empty page break or <pb/> element, are the primary physical structures represented in the markup. Each <pb> element includes an "mmid" attribute identifying the unique ID of a high-resolution scan of that image in the Media Manager application, as well as "audiostart" and "audioend" attributes that identify the section of the audio edition that corresponds to that page. Line breaks (i.e., lineation determined or influenced by the physical constraints of the page rather than compositional choices by the author) are encoded with the empty <lb/> element. No attributes are included in the <lb> element.

Markup of Textual Structure. The journal entry, encoded by a <div1> element with the attribute-value pair "type='Entry'", constitutes the primary textual structure represented in the markup. Each entry contains an <opener> element—which in turn contains a <dateline> element—and one or more paragraphs. Each dateline may include a <name> element with (optionally) a "type" attribute containing one of the following values: city, region; and a <date> element with a "value" attribute whose value is in the form YYYY-MM-DD. The <div1> elements also contain "audiostart" and "audioend" elements that identify the section of the audio edition that corresponds to that entry.

Entries consist of a series of paragraphs. Where indicated by indentation of a line from the left margin of a page, line breaks part-way across a page, or additional white space between lines, paragraphs are encoded with the

element and no attributes.
If present, any prefatory text preceding the dateline may be encoded as a <head> element at the beginning of the entry (i.e., within the <div>element and before the <opener>).

Level of Transcription/Encoding. This markup scheme supports a modest range of presentations, from semi-modernized/corrected to semi-diplomatic. The basic transcription follows the manuscript verbatim. Various manuscript features (e.g., cancellations, interlinear or marginal additions, tears in pages) are encoded, as are regularized versions of proper names and dates and standard versions of nonstandard spellings and expansions of abbreviations.

Extensions to the TEI P5 Schema. The project's Web site contain full details of the markup guidelines:
http://people.cohums.ohio-state.edu/ulman1/LADoaneJournal/DoaneJournalMarkup.cfm
Link to the Doane journal markup guidelines. .

person.education: A Gladys Mary Stephens from Newton, MA appears in lists of "Special Students" in the Boston University Yeark Book for 1907 and 1909, but not for 1908. According to the Year Book for 1907, students could be admitted as special students if they were "taking one or more particular course of work, without being a candidate for a degree," were "deficient on prelimiary preparation," or had "not passed the full number of examinations required for admission" to the class to which they sought admission. Special students were classified in three groups, and Stephens appears in lists of the first group (Group A), "those enrolled in the College [of Liberal Arts] only" (special students in the other groups were enrolled in "Teachers' Courses" or in other departments of the University.
person.bibl: Year Book 1907: 43, 55, 158; Year Book 1909: 44; United States Census, 1920

person.note: In the letter dated August 8, 1909, Gladys mentions her "Uncle Alex" a number of times. It is apparent that he is facilitating social connections for her in Texas, prior to her arrival, so we can assume he lives in El Paso.

person.persName: Stephens, Jennie M. (Mrs. Albert T. Stephens)

person.note: Adelaide's fiance. Gladys never refers to him by name, but tells her mother about his income ($50 per week) and drinking habits ("the man" prefers a good cocktail at his club) in her letter postmarked September 24, 1909. He may also be known as "the Scotchman." In his 8/23/1909 letter to Gladys Stephens, J.J. McIntyre asks about "the Scotchman" and wonders whether this man is "brooke."

person.persName: Diaz, Jose de la Cruz Porfirio
person.note: In her letter to her mother postmarked September 24, 1909, Gladys discusses the political tension in Mexico due to Pres. Diaz' advanced age and the upcoming election. Gladys spells "Diaz" as "Dias." President Diaz was exiled from Mexico in 1911, not long after the start of the Mexican Revolution in 1910, the year following Gladys's visit.
In Gladys's letter to her mother postmarked September 24, 1909, she mentions the Mexican people's opposition towards Vice-President Reyes.

In his letter to Gladys Stephens of 4 October 1909, John J. Macintyre identifies Irene Palmer as the sister of the Purser on the S.S. Northwestern, and indicates that she is 17 years old at the time of the letter. The 1900 U.S. Census records that an Irene Palmer was born in September 1892 in Anderson Island, Washington, which corroroborates her age in Macintyre's letter. The 1900 Census also shows that Irene had two older brothers, which corroborates Macintyre's description of her as the only girl in her family. The 1910 U.S. Census records Irene Palmer's city of residence as Tacoma, which would likely be her city of residence a year earlier at the time of Macintyre's letter dated 04 October 1909. Tacoma's proximity to the Alaska Steamship Company's headquarters in Seattle argues for the plausibility of Irene Palmer hitching a ride to spend time with her brother and to see the landscape of the Pacific Northwest. United States Census, 1900; United States Census, 1910

In his letter to Gladys Stephens of 4 October 1909, John J. Macintyre speaks of spending time with the S.S. Northwestern's purser's sister, whom he identifies as Irene Palmer. Though Macintyre never mentions the purser by name, the 1900 U.S. Census shows that Irene Palmer lived with two older brothers: Gilbert S. and Herbert E. Palmer. The 1910 Census indicates that Gilbert S. Palmer was still a member of the family household, while Herbert E. Palmer is not listed, suggesting that the purser of whom Macintyre speaks is Herbert E. Palmer. In fact, a Herbert E. Palmer corresponding with the relevant genealogical data does not appear at all on the 1910 Census, but this is not surprising if we consider that the itinerant nature of his duties on the Northwestern could have prevented his being recorded for the 1910 Census. It's likely that he didn't die during this gap, as a Herbert E. Palmer matching the relevant genealogical data is recorded in the 1920 Census. At this point, he had married Mary Palmer, a first generation Bohemian-American whose parents emigrated from Bohemia, and the two lived in Pierce County, WA, which includes the greater Tacoma area. The 1930 Census shows that Mary had died and Herbert had moved to Richmond, NY, though it also incorrectly estimates his birth year as 1877. It's likely that even though Macintyre refers to Herbert as Irene Palmer's brother, he was in fact her half-brother. The 1930 Census indicates that both of Herbert's parents were born in Massachusetts, while the head of the Palmer household, Gustavus Palmer, was born in Maine. Herbert's mother, Minnie T. Palmer, was born in Massachusetts, and didn't marry Gustavus until 1882, approximately 6 years after Herbert's birth. United States Census, 1900; United States Census, 1900; United States Census, 1910; United States Census, 1920; United States Census, 1920; United States Census, 1930

person.note: Trey Conatser is a doctoral student specializing in British Romantic literature in the Department of English at The Ohio State University. His research interests include the poetry and poetics of the Romantic period, the Romantic response to the French Revolution, women's writing of the Romantic period, and Romantic long poems by women. Additionally, Trey is interested in digital humanities and editorial and archival work, especially with regard to access, architecture, canonicty, and periodicity. Trey's scholarly writing has been published in New Media & Society and The CEA Critic, and his poetry and other writing has appeared in journals such as Seneca Review, New York Quarterly, Copper Nickel, Mid-American Review, and Prairie Schooner. Between his MA and PhD programs, he taught composition, research and argumentative writing, creative writing, and technical writing at Ivy Tech Community College of Indiana in Indianapolis.

titleStmt.title: Gladys M. Stephens to Mrs. A. T. Stephens, 6 July 1909

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

msContents.p: Stephens describes the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition and the city of Seattle, then reviews her correspondence with friends and family and lists the contents of a package she plans to send to her mother.

physDesc.p: ALS. Four loose sheets of cream-colored Hotel Georgian letterhead stationery measuring 6 x 9.5 inches. The front side contains a 2.5-inch letterhead, a 6.75-inch body with blue lines spaced at .375-inch intervals, and a .25-inch bottom margin. The back side contains a .75-inch unlined head, with the body lined as on the front side. An oval watermark, variably placed on each sheet and measuring approximately 2.375 x 2.625 inches when entirely visible, reads, in outline letters, "MERCHANTS | PRT'G CO | LURIE & LURIE." The letterhead contains, in the upper left-hand corner, a 1.375 x 2.4375-inch halftone image of the Hotel Georgian facade.
physDesc.accMat: Accompanied by a stamped, cancelled, cream-colored envelope of Hotel Georgian stationery measuring 6.5 x 3.625 inches. A 1.375 x 2.4375-inch halftone image of the Hotel Georgian facade is printed on the left-hand side of the envelope above the hotel's address.

div.head:
Photograph of the Hotel Georgian
Photograph of the facade of the Hotel Georgian.
Rates $1.00 up
Hotel Georgian
European Plan
Seattle,_______190___
div.p:
I have made my
first trip to the Exposition
Grounds. They are simply
dreams of beauty. Such
flowers—and such
quantities of them! There
is one place where there
are thousands and
thousands of white,
lavender and pure yellow
pansies. In one place
there are veritable terraces
of water with a falls between
This expanse is surrounded
by the most beautiful
display of poppies I ever
saw. Then there are
flowers like those I brought
home from Senior Prom.—
gerhaniums—dwarf
sweet peas—every kind
of flowers imaginable.
Talk abut roses, there
are so many here that
I can't think what
California will be like.
I went today with
the Virginians. The men
were hunting up old
friends here in the
city. I have a lot of
truck, which I am going
to send by mail. There
are four pictures of
Yellowstone which are
exquisite—they are
as natural as pictures
can be. My Princetonian
got them for me, and
paid a dollar for
them. The packages of tea
I got at the Japanese
tea garden from the
little Japanese girl. I
ordered (through Hayden)
a 5 cent can of condense
milk.

The buildings are fine
at the fair. One of the
Virginian ladies said
this fair is much superior
to the St. Louis and others
because of its compactness
as well as its beauty.
The buildings will be
used later as college b'l'd'gsbuildings.
Today we only visited
those in the inner circle.
The place is laid out in
this way
Layout of the fairgrounds.
A freehand sketch of the layout of the fairgrounds.
The amusement street
is called pay streak—a
mining term.

The city has several
skyscrapers.

There is a Hawaiian
village with real bare
natives. We are going to
visit it later. There also
Esquimos and a village.
I am sending you
also the daily program.
Have not found the
Goulds yet.

This morning it was
raining and I slept until
3
8.25. We went to
the Expo. at 10.30—got
back at 4.40. Some day
we are going up Puget
Sound. I can do quite
a stunt at eating now—
devoured a small steak for
my breakfast—a dish of
strawberries, one of oatmeal,
two muffins and three
pancakes—and a cup of
coffee. Sunburn is wearing
off a trifle since I have
left the park. They have a
line of cable cars here, and
some odd big ones. The
population has increased
150,000 in 2 years.
I am getting to be
quite a critic on buildings
with two builders.

Havent done much on
the writing stunt. I
wrote Miss Childs a
steamer letter, one to
Gus, I think I wrote
one to Roswel, and a
dozen lines to Nat
telling him that I
was having a dandy
time—never knew
where I was going next
and did not know
when I'd be home;
and hoped that he'd
have as pleasant a
summer as I was
having. Found nothing
at the P.O. Gee! but
I'd like to hear. Will
probably be here until
the 20th perhaps
the 24th. Am not sure
as they don't say.
Hope you—all are well.

titleStmt.title: Gladys M. Stephens to Mr. A. T. Stephens, 10 July 1909

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

msContents.p: Gladys Stephens describes a multi-day visit to Yellowstone Park where she drove a coach of four horses for 3 days. She mentions her travel companions "the Virginians" and "some Germans." She describes the exhibits in the Forestry Building at the 1909 Seattle World's Fair. She describes the Forestry Building and comments that the Seattle World's Fair buildings will later be used by Seattle College. She also remarks on Seattle, which she describes as looking "new" but having a number of 12- and 14-story buildings.

The front side contains a 2.5-inch letterhead, a 6.75-inch body with blue lines spaced at .375-inch intervals, and a .25-inch bottom margin. The back side contains a .75-inch unlined head, with the body lined as on the front side. An oval watermark, variably placed on each sheet and measuring approximately 2.375 x 2.625 inches when entirely visible, reads, in outline letters, "MERCHANTS | PRT'G CO | LURIE & LURIE." The letterhead contains, in the upper left-hand corner, a 1.375 x 2.4375-inch halftone image of the Hotel Georgian facade.

Photograph of the Hotel Georgian
Photograph of the facade of the Hotel Georgian.
Rates $1.00 up
Hotel Georgian
European Plan
Seattle,_______190___
div.p:
I do not know
what day we will leave
here, but we'll leave soon.
Will return to El Paso
by way of California.
Have decidedly tanned
from riding up on the
top seat with the driver
in Yellowstone Park.
I drove the coach 3
days. There were 4
horses and the coach
weighs 2400 lbs. It was
against the rules, but
the driver let me! When
we met another coach
or any soldiers the
driver took the reins.
Talk about sore arms!
And my nose, oh my
nose! It was terribly
burned, looked just
like a beet. It has
sealed now and begins
to look more respectable.

With us are some
charming Virginians
and some Germans. We
certainly have good
times. They are all
jolly.

The Exposition is fine
In the Forestry b'l'd'gbuilding
are some pretty big
"sticks." One is 74 ft long
and 4 1/2 ft sq. There is
a cross section of a tree
which is 9 ft. in diam.
There is a hollow tree
trunk which will
hold 50 peoplpeople. The
building is really
mammoth. The columns are huge
trees. I got
what I hope will be
a good picture of it.
All the b'l'd'gsbuildings are fine.
and will be used by
Seattle College later.
Every one who has
been to the other
Expositions say that
This is the best yet.
The city is large and
steadily increasing but
looks very new. There
are lots of large b'l'd'gsbuildings—
plenty of 12 stories and
several 14. There are
some dandy hotels.
Will Ma be home soon?

You had best not ans.answer
This as I will have left
before an ansanswer could
come.

Stephens to Mr. and Mrs. A.T. Stephens dated between 07/06/1909 and 07/30/1909 appear to be sequentially numbered 94, 95, 96, 97, 98, and 99.

figure.head: Two-cent U.S. postage stamp.
figure.figDesc: U.S. POSTAGE / TWO CENTS [Portrait of Washington; perforated horizontally and vertically; Design A139]

div.head:
Photograph of the Hotel Georgian
Photograph of the facade of the Hotel Georgian.
Rates $1.00 up
Hotel Georgian
European Plan
Seattle,_______190___
div.p:
Was awfully
glad to hear from you.
Doubt if we can go to
Alaska— can't get stateroom
so many are going.
Have located the Goulds,
I telephoned today but she
was at the Expo. Got
him on the phone and I
will call later.

Mrs. Hughes (the Virginian)
is a cousin of Mrs. Dana
Gibson and Mrs. Waldorf
Astor (in England) I guess
I'll try and visit them.
Uncle wants me to visit
visit them. Mrs. Jordon
(Mrs. H's cousin) has lots of
money. Her husband died
5 yrs. ago and left a large
estate. One of the sons
"blew in" $40,000 in 2 yrs.
They could buy ranch
for $12,000 and pay $25,000
for improvements. The girl
has her money too. Her
mink coat only cost $600.
I might do worse than
to visit the family don't
you think. They tried to
have me promise to visit
them.

Not much to write
about now so I guess
that I'll stop.
Now Judy dear do take
things easy.

titleStmt.title: Gladys M. Stephens to Mrs. A.T. Stevens, 6 September 1909

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

msContents.p: Gladys is waiting for mother's (A.T. Stevens) letter, is something wrong? Alaska ring arrived. Pillow.

physDesc.p: One sheet of cream-colored paper measuring 5.5 x 8.11 inches folded in half and written on front and back. The progression of text goes front right, back right, back left, front left. Contains a hollow font watermark that reads "Saw & Co. / Boston".
physDesc.accMat: Accompanied by a stamped (stamp is upside down), cancelled, cream-colored envelope measuring 2.8 x 4.25 inches. On the left side of the envelope written sideways in an unknown, penciled hand is the statement "Hold 9-10-09."

ab.stamp: U.S. POSTAGE / [Portrait of George Washington; perforated on three edges; upside down; Design A139] / TWO CENTS

div.p:
What is
the trouble, are you
sick? I looked and
looked for a letter
today, but none
came. I declare
if I don't get
one tomorrow I
will send a
telegram to
to Berenice Smith.
It is pretty warm
here now, yet
there was a big
rain last night.

My Alaska
ring came here
the 23 of Aug.. I
got it this morning. It is
a beauty.

Oh about the
pillow. Mrs. L. was
much pleased
with it and thought
it handsome and
it is in the
parlour.

I do hope that
I'll get a letter
tomorrow.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

msContents.p: Gladys tells her mother of the group's return to Seattle; anticipates a visit to a wealthy Texan's ranch; makes ambiguous references to what we would assume is news or gossip of friends and acquaintances from home; mentions correspondence with a few other individuals; and brags about being shown around by Uncle Alex and the "plans for next summer" already in the works.

physDesc.p: This original letter contains five loose sheets of cream-colored Hotel Georgian letterhead stationery measuring 6 x 9.5 inches. They have been folded in half and folded together. The front side contains a 2.5-inch letterhead, a 6.75-inch body with blue lines spaced at .375-inch intervals, and a .25-inch bottom margin. The back side is unlined. An oval watermark, variably placed on each sheet and measuring approximately 2.375 x 2.625 inches when entirely visible, reads, in outline letters, "MERCHANTS | PRT'G CO | LURIE & LURIE." The letterhead contains, in the upper left-hand corner, a 1.375 x 2.4375-inch image of the Hotel Georgian facade. It should be noted that other letters in the collection, even as recently as the letters written by Gladys in July from the same hotel, are likewise composed on Hotel Georgian stationery, but some time in the interim of Gladys's excursion to Alaska, the Hotel Georgian modified its stationery slightly. The image is now an illustration rather than a photo, and depicts the hotel facade from a more diagonal angle (we see proportionally more of the side of the building. The font of the letterhead has also changed (tending toward more of a block style than the slanted script) and minor additions have been made. Near the top border of the paper, the hotel owner's names are printed ("D. Swinehart" and "Fred G. Caldwell"), and new qualifiers have been added under the "Hotel Georgian" moniker. The hotel stationery no longer includes a partially printed dateline ("Seattle, ________190____"), and so Gladys has handwritten the date ("8/8/.09") near the bottom, and slightly left of center, inside the bounded letterhead. On subsequent pages, she numbers the pages by hand, again within the boundaries of the letterhead, and in virtually the same place each time but not always in the same style (some page numbers are followed by periods, some by nothing, and one is underlined).
physDesc.accMat: Accompanied by a stamped, cancelled, cream-colored envelope of Hotel Georgian stationery measuring 6.5 x 3.625 inches. A 1.375 x 2.4375-inch photographed image of the Hotel Georgian facade is printed on the left-hand side of the envelope above the hotel's address. Incidentally, the image of the hotel on the envelope corresponds with the image of the hotel facade on the outdated Hotel Georgian stationery. The stamp is also upside down.

div.p:
We arrived in Seattle
at 7:20 this morning. It was
rather rough last night, but
it was just from the wind.
It was the only rough place we
had coming back. We had a
dandy time coming back.

As a souvenir I have the
official list of the passangers
who sailed from Seattle. It
was posted by the Purser, and he gave it to me.

I'd like to know what is
the matter with auntie. I
sent her cards from Yellowstone
and some from here — among
them a leather A.Y.P.card.
I sent her some from Alaska.
also. Almost every time I
sent you one I sent her one.

I was not sick once while I
was gone. I am enough fatter
so that the people here at the
hotel spoof of it. I'm more
tanned also.

A Texasjudge who is worth
3 million was on the ship coming
back with his wife, two daughters
and 2 grandsons. He owns a ranch
in Texaswhich is about 12
miles square. They have invited
me to visit them, and Uncle
Alexwants me too. He may
have a business motive. I
will likely stop there for 2 or 3
days. He wants to take me to
a real southern hunt. I can
have a pony all for myself he
said. It is an opportunity not
to be lost, don't you agree?

We had a great time last night-
our last on board. No one turned
in before 12 some not until
2. I did at 12. It seems awfully
funny to be on land again.
They certainly were glad to see
us here at the hotel.

Well you never can tell what people will do. Waltcertainly
seems to be the limit. As for
his mother they areshe is the
limit.

So you like the Thomases?
What is that about Berenice? Do
you believe it?

I fail to see the point of Mrs.
Rich'sjoke. So the tree didn't
bloom.

I did notsend a card to
Will Ward. I sent
it to his mother !

He is a cheerful lyerlier. I
have not sent any more to the
Dotens. Do not worry. I got a
letter from Waltwhich I will
enclose. In it he acknowledges
one letter.

I did not have any hat on
while I was gone. I'm sending
a large envelope with one or
too things I do not want lost.

I got your five letters this
morning, and one from Walt,
and one from Adelaide. I'm not
sure whether Adelaide is going
to Mexico or not.

The Mexicantrip is all planned
and I start home immediately
on getting back. I'll be about
one week late. U.A.Uncle Alexhas the day
set for us to start to Mexicoand
all plans O.K.

He wants me to see all the
people whom he knows. He has
told them about my coming for
so long. I'm doing my best I
assure you. I guess I'm
succeeding fairly well. He is
so tickled he does not know
what to do. He is starting plans
for next summer already.
We are "on" for the pictures.
Heaps of love
Neddy

postscript.p:
Address next letters to
Los Angeles
General Delivery

titleStmt.title: J.J. McIntyre to Gladys M. Stevens, 8-13-1909

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

msContents.p: An eight page love letter plus envelope

div.p:
It was with pleasure that
I received your Cards + letter
this P.M. but Sorry that
you did not enjoy your trip
And got Such a disagreable place
to Stop and I don't like Mr
Holland a bit for taking you
there and if your feelings at
the Depot was any thing like
mine you Certainly have my
Sympathy for dear I did not
eaveneven wait untilluntil the train pulled
out
I knowed that you were not feeling
your best So I did not tell you
the promise that I wished from
you but asked in last letter?
And when Mr Holland asked you
if they was any tears shed
And allwaysalways remember honey I
have two Sholdersshoulders a right + also a left
one And you can have your choice
or both? by the -- way how is
our (I was going to Say little) unkleuncle
getting along better I hope?

I dare not express my feelings
in regards to the place where Holland
recommended but honey I said
Somefing ossle naughty --

I don't Care I was mad to think
of my little girl being in Such
a place If I Could only binbeen there
but dear I can never wait 2 years
before I see you I simply cant
It Seamsseems almost a year now
And the good old Santa Clara She
or he (as it is a mail boat) is a friend
of mine And I may Soon be back
again the Chief was down to See me
last night and he don't want me
to make this trip So I Saw the Supt
engrto day and he transferred me to
the North Western She he Sails
Monday #16 And he Said If he got
Any more news from Santa Clara
he would hold me over untill She he
Sails and that means $1200 per year
&expenses I didn't mind before

But now -- Neddie
I have not binbeen over to See my mother
Since you left for the moment She
Saw me She would want to know the
trouble And the memory of last
Voigevoyage is totoo Sweet to Share with eaveneven
my Mother as yet but I am gradually
Coming back to Earth! I only hope
I recieve your letter before I go North
again I hate to leave at all but
I must! I was very much pleased
to hear Uncle A's opinion of me
And I hope it will allwaysalways be the
Same or Improve if any thing!
"And the Small heap grows to an
enormous Size! (this to you pet)
for I will watch every little
word for Simptomssymptoms of the heap.
improving for the better
And honey tell me all the troubles
as well as pleasures So I may share
them with you as I really feel
As I am reading your letters that
I am with you I was up town
this afternoon and Saw a few
Texas hats but not the right one
or the right face but I did not
stay long and am staying aboard
to night I have not binbeen to the fair
Since and do not think I will go again
I can saflysafely make the promise never
to Smoke cigaretts again and regards
to Drink It will be a bitter dissaperiture
that will ever Start me again it fully
makes me Shudder to think of you being
Any where near that Class in portland
And I hope you will have a better
time in San francisco!

if we only had had a little time to
ourSelves the night before on the
morning you Sailed how much
better I would have felt for I
Cannot make my Self believe
but what Something will happen
Forgive me dear if that Seamesseems
unjust but It Seamesseems totoo good to last
but will live in hopes!

Mr Jones was enquiringinquiring about today
And he told me if I heard from you
to remind you of the picture you
know which one.

well neddy the lights will be
agoing out Soon as it is nearing 10 P.M.
give my very best regards to uncle E
And Some to Mr Holland and remember
I am anxiously awaiting a reply
to last letter which is on the
road before this And I hope to
have Heaps of letters with heaps
of love on my return from
this Voigevoyage I will write again
before Sailing so you will know
how + where I am
Good ByGoodbye little girl
div.closer:
I Remain as Ever Yours in big
"Heaps"J McIntyre
+ lightboat
"Note Date"
Friday 13th / 09

titleStmt.title: Cora L. Anderson to Mrs. A. T. Stephens, 19 August 1909

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

div.ab:
new baby
by neice
9—F The penciled number here doesn't seem to match the pattern on the other envelopes since the second digit is a letter rather than a number. This endorsement also includes a description of the contents of the letter.

figure.head: Two-cent U.S. postage stamp.
figure.figDesc: UNITED STATES / OF AMERICA / POSTAGE / TWO CENTS [Portrait of Washington; perforated horizontally and vertically]

div.p:
Please dontdon't
feel that I have neglected
you more than others for
we have had so much on our
minds and hands for the last
few weeks that we have left
almost everyone else out.
We have a nice baby boy. A
good big baby, not a little
teeny weeny. You know I
wished for a small baby, but
now that he is here I am glad
he is strong and perfect. If
I can only keep him well I
shall be happy. I am not very
strong yet but am gaining
every day a little, but I shall have to be
careful for awhile yet. Gladys is pleased
with her little brother and Willis is pleased
with his little son. I have only heard from
Gladys Stevens once. She was then in Colorado.
I had hoped she would keep me posted as to
her travels. I supposed she will be home before
a great while now with many, many entertaining
things to tell you. I have thought of her very
often. Give my love to her when you see or write
her and tell her about my baby boy. You must
have missed her a very great deal. I hope you
are well. I am not able to do any house work yet.
Must not write any more this time. With love
I remain

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

figure.head: Two-cent U.S. postage stamp.
figure.figDesc: U.S. POSTAGE / TWO CENTS [Color-Red and Upside down]

div.p:
As I am now standing my last
watch before arriving at Juneau
and I am still a wondering
and lonesome as usual I thought
I would write a friend
which will probably be the
last chance to mail unless they
is a farther north than
which seldomeseldom happiness
It is now 1:30 a.m. as I am
still on the same 12/4 as I was
on Santa Clara and we should
arrive in Juneau about noon and
I do not know how long we will
be there and cannot say if I
can get up to see about the pictures
but will try.

As I said before Neddy dear I am writing
on watch so please excuse pencil and a
few finger marks you will I know
tell Uncle athat we have good
school teachers aboard this time and
I think he could enjoy him self
and Neddy I have found a sweet
little girl aboard and her name
is Gladys So you know she must
be Ok. She seames very fond of me
and gave me a kiss the first time I
saw her but honey the poor little
thing is only 2 years old So don't know
any better. we are having very smooth
weather so far but plenty of rain
we crossed Mill bank sound yesterday
do you remember that place I
do that so the first time
I ever had the pleasure of speaking
to you and how bad you felt I think
I could have a little more sympathy
if we ever have the pleasure of
crossing there together again
don't you honey?
which I hope will be no later than
the spring of 1910 do you? Tell me
this is the first time in a long time
that I hated to leave Seattle on account
of not being there when my letter
arrived and again when I am at sea
well I know where I am at
least. I had two letters before sailing
this time one Sunday and one Monday
at 6 p.m. from a passenger that
went north on this boat last
spring but which I did not talk
to but twice but she had a notion
or fancy but Neddie dear the
answers to both were the same
and was this—Impossible
to see you am totoo busy that's all
and the season. Neddy would not like
it and what a different feeling
comes over one when they have done
what they know to be wrightright Indeed
it is a pleasure.

you said twoto always remember and
do nothing for which your mother
would be ashamed of you.

well little girl well do I remember
the talkings I used to get as a young
fellow when going out with the boys
as it were or to a party or dance
how well do I remember in late years
how she has talked to me by the hour
to be a better boy one for a mother
to be proud of in her old age and
the last words I hear on leaving
home dear is this remember mother
prays for her boy every night do
you wonder Neddy how a boy or
man could thing to be
ashamed of "But honey I have"
but did not realize it untilluntil I met
you honey what a differene between
a mothers affections and the
one girl or the only boy which we
are bound to meet some day I do not
know if you can understand
my feelings in this or not but
please tell me will you dear please
if you only knew with what pleasure
I read your letters and watch for
any little words that will lead me
to think of heapeimproving
how I wonder what your mother
would think of me if she saw me
how I wonder what you think of
these letters of mine with us being
of quite a different desposition in
a way. Me of a very affectionate
turn of mind and you not so much
so but every thing has binbeen so
unusalunusual and out of the ordinary
that I sometimes wonder how
it all happened do you honey
be shoresure and tell me what you
think honey of these please do
I wonder if you knew how I
Uncle a two little good
night kisses which I saw him
yet But enough of this for envy
is the habit of extracting misery
from other peoples happiness.
I wonder what influence it
would have on you to have some
one put up an argument against
me for instance
passing fancy and a hundred
others but I will trust my
little girl untilluntil she tells me
diffarantedifferent than what I now believe.

You asked me if I knew the story
of the red rose "remember how dense
at times" but I can tell you the future
of one little rose if you wish
be shoresure and tell me of your trip
and how you are enjoying your self
be shoresure and ask as many questions
as you like do not be afraid honey
for I will understand.

Oh how much I would give
for one or two more nights
on Santa Clara with you now
how much could be said
and how much better we could
understand but here we are
Dear me plowing along miles
farther away every day when it
is my desire to be with you
do you know the other day well it
was after I finished reading the
first little letter I was talking to
the Chief "he calls me his boy also"
all at once he grabbed me by
the arm and shookedshook me an said
wake up boy what's the matter
can you think where my mind
was. Ms Hollinds remark does not
surprise me much honey I am getting
them now every day while
I was around the docks it was
Hellow Mack you look lonesome
this with a knowing smile.
They say absence makes theethe heart
grow fonder I do not hafhave to
worry about mine I have none
I wonder where it went it
I sent in the room honest Dear
tell me if you know please
well Neddy dear it is nearing
4 a.m. I but you are glad for I
will hafhave to close

but be shoresure and tell me all the
news from home tell me if I am
asking totoo much well
honey tell me everything
that isnt asking much is it
give my best to Uncle a
and

now I will bid you Goodnight
or rather good morning

titleStmt.title: Gladys M. Stephens to Mrs. A. T. Stephens, 22 July 1909

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

msContents.p: This letter details Gladys's evaluation of Adelaide's wedding purchases and fiance, as well as Gladys's experience with head lice, which she picked up in Mexico. Gladys also explains to her mother that she is staying in Mexico longer than she originally planned so she can see the President before he dies. She briefly explains the political tension in Mexico between Vice-President Reyes and the general populace.

div.p:
Adelaide is getting some lovely
things to be married in. She is having
a pale blue broadcloth dress made. She
has a handsome brown suit. Things are
getting quite interesting I can tell
you. Just between you and I "the man""the man"
has one bad feature. He takes a cocktail
now and then. No one here seems to
mind it. And of course I have said
nothing. He seems nice other ways and
every one speaks well of him. He has
a good position and makes in the
vicinity of $50 a week. Well all's
well that end's well. $50 a week
and all I would not marry him.
Of course he belongs to the club here and
the club's favorite drink is cocktail. I've
noticed the odor about everytime I've
seen him.

I have found out some startling
information today. I went to the
hairdressers to have a shampoo.
On account of the amount of alkali
in the water people can not wash
their hair with it themselves. Adelaide
and I made arrangements to go together
this morning. What do you suppose
the woman found--bugs in
my head! I got them in Mexico.
They all told me I'd be apt
to get them. I thought I'd escaped
however. Now what do you think
of that. Well she worked good
and hard and dosed my head and
I have to go again Sat. morning.
Their deposit was not large and
so we have hopes of soon cleaning
it all out. You can imagine
how I feel. There isn't on the
average one American in ten
who goes there without getting
loaded. Here's hoping I'll be clear
of it all soon.

Unclesays I must stay to
see the Presidents meet and then I
can go home immediately after
that. He says Dias is so old (79) that
I probably will never get another
chance to see anything of the kind
again. A revolution in Mexico is
imminent if Dias dies. The Vice
Pres.ReyesPres. Reyes wants to be Pres. and
the people hate him terribly. They
have to have Rurales every where to
keep them quiet now even. He
simply will not hear of my going
before they meet. He said that he
knew you would understand when
I explained the situation to you. I
shall have every thing ready to go as
soon as I can leave after it's over.
The old citizens are going to have a
big time and he wants me to be
with him. Lots better today. Slept 12 hrs.
Hope you are better

titleStmt.title: Gladys M. Stephens to Mrs. A. T. Stephens, 5 October 1909

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

figure.head: Two-cent U.S. postage stamp.
figure.figDesc: U.S. POSTAGE / TWO CENTS [Portrait of Washington; perforated horizontally and vertically; Design A139]

div.p:
Have just
returned from a
birthday luncheon
and this evening
I am going out to
dinner at another
house.

It is as warm
today as a July
day at home. It
will be cool this
evening however.

I am as well as
ever.

Adelaide is
getting along
finely with her
shopping. Her
evening hat will
cost $52.95. How's that?
Everything else
accordingly.

I am wondering
what you think
of the pictures.
They were taken
in San Diego
and that dress
was all I could
wear. There was
no primping for
those pictures I
can tell you.

Got your card
yesterday.

Were you
surprised about
the pictures? We
wanted you to
be.

Here they're all
talking about
my return —and
I haven't left yet.
What do you think
of that?

Just wrote to
Pauline. Will
mail it when I
get time.
Hope you are well.

div.ab:
Miss. Gladys. M. Stephens .
Los Angeles.
California (General Delivery)
126 Leon St. El Paso Tex

figure.head: Two-cent U.S. postage stamp.
figure.figDesc: U.S. POSTAGE / TWO CENTS [Portrait of William Seward; perforated horizontally and vertically; U.S. #370] Upside down

div.p:
once more I am writing on the last
watch before arriving in port and in
the wee hours of the morning I promised
my self to let you down easy this
time and not write so much but it
promises to be a long watch for
we are running dead slow looking
for a prominent Cape! Cape St
Elias by name. and a watch under
a slow Bell is always a long one
for me. I was just up stairs
and it is a nasty rainy night
and the ship is roaling heavy. you
should ought to see my pose in writing this the Kangaroo is not in it.
I wonder how you would fellfeel
better I hope. we are agoing
to ValdeseValdese first the mail hastohas to be
delivered at a certain time and we
are behind but what's the odds no
mail for me and a dozen or two
letters would be very nice to me but
nothing doing untilluntil Seattle again!
I started to read a story last night
called the Holy City and It promises
to be good. A few lines which I gave
special attention to were these

A certain boy and a certain girl aggreedagreed
to go to goto the same place in the same
boat and they both pulled together So
what's the odds where they came from?
do you aggreeagreewith them.
One offof the many things that
you will be told is this honey He's
only a seafaring man. and I will
will admit that their Rep. is none
too good but that comes more from
the sailor class on war ships and
sailing vessels and all deapdeep water crafts
mostly foreigner's and dear I hope tooto
be through with this in the near
future hence them long 2 years if
you can call that near future.
and again Burns says a man's
a man for all o that "and that"!
By the way how is the Scotchman
getting along not "brooke""broke" I hope I
must laugh when I think of the
lookson ouncle A's face the day you
were In the Engine room I didn't
think you noticed. but you afterwards
spoke about it no harm for me
you asked about my father he was doing nicely when I lift thank you neddy

we arrived in Juneau @ 11 40 and left 12 40
So did not have a chance to see about Santa
Clara's pictures but may next time I
will not forget them any way when
I have the time to get up town
I have no pictures of my self but
will have some some day and send
you one If you wish and don't
forget that I have only the postal
which by the way is in use every
day honey and many thanks for
that pleasure but the original is
what I wish to see above all else!
Never satisfied am I honey
but hope to be some day live in
hopes and - I know sisintit isn't
nice to be so selfish but it would
be osslealso nice to see you tonight or any
other time the sooner the quicker
It is now 3 a.m. and still running
slow. I suppose you are having a nice
quiet sleep long one this I hope so
I also hope you are having a nice time
and have saw lots of interesting places
I do not know if theythere is a boat north
of us or not but am taking a chance
any way it makes me seem closer
to you anyway to be writing
away and at the sam time going
farther + farther away take notice
I am always looking out for my own
pleasure when at the same time I may
be trying your patiences surely
hope not honey deed I do

I had a great romp with little
Gladys tonight her mother fetched
her to my window (I have a room
same as the chiefs on Santa Clara only
the door opens in engine room instead
of deck) and she hollered for uncle that's
what she calls me and I and I took her
in side gave her an orange door
to the engine room and she wasn't
a bit afraid and it was a pleasure
twoto have only a wee Gladys
to talk to and I said lots
of things to her about -O well-
well she laughed and seemed to
enjoy it any way although
could not understand

I almost believe honey that I
could carry you the same if
the opportunity could be and your
permission do you
I often wonder If you give
me little thought when alone
at night after a day of pleasure
of pleasure - I hope) remember
dear I am going over the same
old rout nothing new and
nothing to do but think which
is not altogether unpleasant for
neddy they are always of you how
glad I will be to get back to Seattle
to get my letters so much seems to
depend on them how I wished I
knew what your mother said
for I want to tell my mother
all about you on my return
but nothing to do but wait and
wish for the best is they dear
I forgot to tell you I gave up
my room in Seattle also my friend
or at least he was supposed to be
They have just whistled down from
the bridge for 5 more Reverlitions
So theythere will be something doing in
a short time and the time is 3 40 and
I must write up my log so once more
little girl I will bid you good night

closer.salute: wif a heaps of love XX

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

msContents.p: Black Ball line; Alaska; passengers; freight.

physDesc.p: ALS. Two loose sheets of cream-colored Alaska Steamship Company letterhead stationary measuring 8 X 10.75 inches. The front side contains a 2.75 inch letterhead, a body with blue lines spaced at 0.375 inch intervals, and a 0.375 inh bottom margin. The letterhead is stamped "FORM 1 10M 8-09" and a 2.75 inch line, followed by "190" and another 0.25 inch line. The letterhead contains, in the upper-left hand corner, a half-tone logo for the "ALASKA | STEAMSHIP Co. | BLACK BALL | LINE" 1 inch on all sides.
physDesc.accMat: Accompanied by a stamped, not-cancelled manilla-colored 6.5 X 3.75 inch envelope, stamped JUNEAU | SEP | 13 | 1909 | 8 PM | ALASKA. The envelope is stamped in the upper-left hand corner "FORM 7 M.P. 20 M 5-09".

div.p:
well we arrived & deaparted from ketchukam all OK and
will be in Taku (you were there" about 630 and Should be in Juneau 930 a.m and leave for Skagway by 11 00
then we go to Chilkoot for 3000 Cases of Salmon
and then to Gypsum you remember the last place
it is the place that we were agoinggoing to Stop at after leaving
Sitka but for Some reason did not, from Gypsum
to Ketchikan to Belling Run and there Tacoma and me
mithermother; we are having no end of fun this trip they was a
boat lift Seattle the Same time we did and we have binbeen racing
all the way up this Companys boat too a freight boat
we have accomadations for about >5 passengers on this one
and a fine passenger list we have this time a nice large
healthy looking bunch but very quiet I have not
binbeen able to get of them to talk to me they seem afraid
they are all Montana and are agoinggoing to Skaguay
well we beat to Ketchkan about 3/4 of a hour but they
had no Cargo for there So left ahead of us but they
mit S.S. Dolphin and had to change Peluts So we
caught up with them and at it again we were

side by each for about 3 hours and they turned off
and went another way they go direct to Skag and is
45 or 50 miles farter than the way we are going but
we make 3 stops So I do not know how we will
make out but are doing our best the worst of it is I
was abooard of .S. Santa AnnaS Sailing night and was
Joshing the Chief about the old freight boat that was on and
if they beat us to Skag I will never hear the last of it
he is the Chief from S.S. Ohio and as I said before an auld
acquantance of mine; well honey I've binbeen after sending that postal
Carrier down to see how the knife is getting along; Yes I heard the
name of one of the passengers who Seames to be a little bolder
than the rest and her name is Maud 126 head of cattle
and 3 mules and they all seem to be enjoying the trip and getting
along nicely; well we are getting along better than I thought;
we have a "Stand By" now So will say good by for a little while
Hello - well brother Snow and I made the dock all right and
we will be away in a short time; well little girl I have
binbeen wondering how you are enjoying your Trip and how
you will like Mexico you will undoublily See Some
very interesting places doon there, I hope. So any
way! but never mind dear If every thing goes all
I wish (I don't want much do Honey) we will have
the trip of your life Some day and will be to China
& Japan and on down to Manila; Manila is a very
Interesting place the old walled City for Instance
I have some Souvenirs from there or did have
any way but most every one that comes to the
house takes Something away and sometimes I
do not like it for some of the things has a
history that is Interesting for me anyway

and how I would like to see you on going
in Some of the Silk and Curioe Shops you would
Certainlly do Some talking with those brown eyes
I know: "what I finkthink" how I would like to
see you this morning or tonight ore anytime and
all times; I wished you knew how I have felt
since I got your last letters every thing looks brighter
and I am as happy as a kid you call me big boy
well Sometimes I hardly think I'm that But I
Suppose we will be old long enough So we
might as well be kids as long as possible and
there is only one little Cloud and that is I cannot See
you as often as I wish; But "Patience"It may not
allways be this way I don't finkthink so any way do you (NO)you needn't answer that honey Those about
that #110 did you make it while resting up at El Paso
hope So well your last letters was in Ketchikan only
about 3 hours lucky wasnt I but dont Know how
long this one will be in Juneau when the Postman
Comes along with Some of these letters dear you will
be looking out for the if poessman to see if my honk
is coming next I'm afraid

I was thinking last night after going to bed
if I have the pleasure of meeting seeing you again in the
Depot if our faces will be as large as last time
I don't finkthink so do you honey does not? I wonder how
this fellow knew how I was a going to feel?
" 'Tell her, tell I see
Those eyes, I do not live--that Rome to me
Is hatefull--tell her--oh!--I know not what--
That ever thought and feeling, space and spot,
Is like an ugly dream where she is not;
All persons plagues; all living wearysome;
All talking empty . . . Quotation from Elanor Glyn's novel Three Weeks, set in Rome and Venice. (Glyn 178)
There Goes the whistle and So long for a ittle minnit
well dear I hope you get Some letters before you go to Mexico
City or You will not know what to think has happened
to me; But when you get back to El Paso or home
they will not be So much delay and I also hope that I
will have "heaps" of letters when I get home the 22nd or 23rd
well dear ittle I must Say So long and will write again
from Skaguay give my very best regards to uncle alex
and Love to ned I Remain The Same

titleStmt.title: Glady M. Stephens to Mrs. A.T. Stephens, 27 September, 1909

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

physDesc.accMat: Accompanied by a stamped, cancelled, cream-colored envelope on unknown stationery measuring 6 x 3.5-inch. A 2.5 x 2-inch halftone image of Oregon Timber is printed on the left-hand side of the envelope.

figure.head: Two-cent U.S. postage stamp.
figure.figDesc: U.S. POSTAGE / TWO CENTS [Portrait of Washington; perforated horizontally and vertically; Design A139]

div.p:
I have just written
to Ivalor and will send her
little box this afternoon by
registered mail

I'm feeling lots better
than when I came up
from Mexico, I am also look-
ing better and have begun
to gain back some of what
I lost in the City. As to the
"bugs" we'll I'm progressing
with them too. Fortunately
I didn't get many. I'm
going to the hair dresser this
afternoon or in the morning.

I'm going to show Mrs. L.
how to cook Boston Baked
Beans some day this week.
It is to be a surprise for
the men text— if they come out.
well.

She will show me how to
make tamalies and also how
to eat them so she says.

Adelaide is head over
heels in dressmaking.
She isn't doing it though.
The day is not settled
yet, but it will probably
be the first week of
Nov. November

She thinks that she
will want me to write
to
Calif. California for ostrich plumes
for her.

She is 7 lbs.
pounds heavier than
I am.

All roads lead back to
Rome - amd with Adelaide
all talk turns to "the West."

So Jack Ward is married. He
deserves all he may get. Where
are they living?
I got a card from Berenice.

Yes, Alice Wunner would
make you tired, but that
was always the way. The
last word I sent her was
from the City of Mexico.

Have you seen anything
of Maynard? If wirsed he'd
be there sometime. How is
Florence carrying sail?

How on Earth could the Riches go to
Me. Maine ?

I sent Mrs. Duff a card
from Mexico

Who is in the Ward's
Pd. Portland
house? I suppose Miss
Camys bell is still scirtching
along.

How are the Thomases by
this time?
Never heard from Philys.

The last card I sent to
Mabel Nims was so long
ago that I've forgotten
when it was.

Haven't heard from
Rosinel lately

Got a letter from the
Jays giving me his
address, but had mailed
a note the night before
to Boston.

Have you heard from the
Maca's lately. I wonder
what the madam thinks
now?

Hope you are well.
So long for now
Love
Gladys
9/27/09

titleStmt.title: John J. Macintyre to Gladys M. Stephens, 04 October 1909

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University
msIdentifier.collection: Dr. Ivan S. Gilbert collection of Stephens family travel letters, 1834-1949 1909-1917

msContents.p: Ship schedule and route for the S.S. Northwestern; spending time with the Purser's sister; pictures received from Gladys; specifications of the Northwestern compared to the Santa Clara; auto accidents.

physDesc.p: Two loose sheets of dirty white Alaska Steamship Company letterhead stationery measuring 10.875 inches by 8.5 inches, with light blue horizontal lining on the recto beginning 2.75 inches from the top and spaced .375 inches apart. Above the lining, centered at the top of the page, and measuring 4.25 inches by .25 inches is "Alaska Steamship Company", below which and right-justified is a solid black line interrupted by "190" for the date of composition. Measuring approximately 1 inch by 1 inch at the top left corner of the recto is the Alaska Steamship Company logo, reading "Alaska | Steamship Co. | Black Ball | Line" over a black sphere in front of a staff and flag with a black circle centered on a white background. At the extreme top left of the recto, in small block text, is "form 1 10m 8-09". A variably and transversally placed watermark is visible on the right side of the recto, reading "Shawano | Mills". The watermark is variably and horizontally truncated by the right edge of the recto through "Shawano", which measures roughly 5 inches horizontally and would measure 1 inch vertically if the letters were not truncated. "Mills" measures roughly 3 inches by 1 inch.
physDesc.accMat: Accompanied by a cream colored envelope measuring 5.4375 inches by 3.125 inches, postmarked for Seattle, Wash. on Oct 5, 1909. The postmarked time of day is only partially legible. The cancellation reads "World's | Fair | Seattle | 1909" in a sected compartment. A comma-like marking in a circle is inscribed in pencil on the bottom quadrant of the back of the envelope, and a "9" followed by a circled "28½" is written in pencil on the right side of the back of the envelope.

figure.head: Two-cent U.S. postage stamp.
figure.figDesc: U.S. POSTAGE / TWO CENTS [Portrait of Washington; perforated horizontally and vertically; Design A139]

div.head:

Logo of the Alaska Steamship Company
Logo of the Alaska Steamship Company Black Ball Line
Alaska Steamship Company

div.p:
well honey I will be In Seattle tonight about
1132 I fink! That's bad for I cannot get my mail
untilluntiltomorrow, we bmissed the tide in SeymorSeymour
narrows and had to Anchor for 4 hours and that's
the reason why. I do hope I will have a letter
from El Paso Saying you got there all O.K. but
I am afraid I will haftohave to wait another day
At least! how I would like to See you dear (how I
would) And See if theythere is any Change in my little
girl with all her travels I don't fink So—hope not
any way! we are a day ahead of time on the time
I Set as we only have a half a cargo It looks bad
for another trip fbut ofcorseof course cannot tell untilluntil
we get home, I hope we do not lay up as
I have quite enough changes for one year let's
See 5 Ships all the Same tramp Engineer
A "tramp engineer" designates an engineer who has little formal training and learns on the job. Additionally, this kind of engineer is an interloper of sorts, frequently moving from job to job. In The Engineers' Review volume 16 (1905), I. C. Loyd defends the tramp engineer as competent compared to the the traditional worker allied to one or two jobs, even though the tramp engineer also "won't work in a place long enough to get married to the job. They like new scenes and experiences and won't take back talk from anybody" Loyd. It's unclear if Macintyre is stating that he has worked with literally the same person on five different ships, or that he has found all the tramp engineers to be frustratingly similar. The latter seems more likely considering the pervasive negativity towards tramp engineers. we have had
exceedingly fine weather this Vo igeVoyage It did intdidn't
even have Sense enough to rain only once we have
the Crew the Cannery crew from Klawock(this is
the way it is Klaw-wock) and no Totem
Tuxekan was renowned for its totem poles, and Klawock created a Totem Park to display authentic and replica totem poles, which Macintyre seems to anticipate here "Visitor Information". The preservation effort doesn't seem to be isolated, as a 1927 New York Times article laments the Alaskan Indians' "scant regard for the ritual of the old tradition" of totem-making and relates the need for "funds for the preservation of these monuments" "Deserted Totems of Alaska".
yet honey
we arrived at Klawock at 93828 -9-/29 —and left 1230 -9-30
and I expected to be there at least 24 hours and the Indian
Village is acrostacross the bay from the Cannery
"[T]he first cannery in Alaska was built [in Klawock] by a San Francisco firm in 1878." Until 1920, it remained the only salmon cannery in the state "Visitor Information". and that's
why! we waswere in Ketchikan about 2 hours coming
home the PursersPurser's Sister and I went up to the
falls the lower ones honey not way up the where
we went She got Some Pictures! It was a fine day and
She is good Company—But—what a differance difference from
the last time I was there! She is only 17 years of age
and the only girl of the family and you Can See She has binbeen
in the havbit of having her own way and She Is quite a little
flirt—but a nice girl. She Cannot understand me at all, as the
Purser and my selfI is are the only two on the Ship that
hasenthaven't a little wife and large family (the Chief's #2 20)
and this Ship Carries no freight C rlerk the purser has that
work to look after and So It has binbeen up to me to show her around!
and It SeemesSeems quite nice to have Some one of my own
age to talk to (honest that's allI am) I gave her a long talk Sat Saturday night
about her fellows, and her self she did not like it a littl little
bit but had to listen all the Same! I have not SawSeen her Since
yes all right (Irene Palmer) speaking of pictures dear
I fink the world of that one you sent me, but honey haventhaven't
you got your harehair Comed Combed differantdifferently than when you were
here! I fink So and listen dear did you know that you
waswere agetting a lttlelittle kiss every night about 930 well you
are—See how I take advantage of you when you are not here
take notice tonight honey at that time and see if you Can Catch me
at It—I wonder oif you will be So Economical with
then when I See you again hope not Si sent nice of you I fink
tell me dear
I do not know if I told you about the Northwestern
or not! Yes She Is a big Ship about 3 timesmore the power
ofthan Santa Clara. She had about 3000 horshorse powpower (now do you
know—no—well perhaps you Can get a better Idea
this way Engine room Crews Northwestern 25 men
Santa Clara 13—and this Soap box
Here Macintyre seems to be referring to the boat on which he's currently sailing to catch up with the Northwestern. The diminutive connotation fits with the boastful tone that he has assumed to impress Gladys with the size and power of the Northwestern. Interestingly, the term "soap box" hasn't yet entered common usage as a way of designating a smaller, unpowered or low-power vehicle. 8 — Northwestern 6 boilers
Clara 2 Northwestern burns 70 tons coal in 24 hours Clara
28 or 30 the Northwestern is only a day ahead of us now
and She is 11 or 12 days behind time must have had all kinds
of trouble with her boilers they are in a dangerous
Condition but I like her just the Same If Someone
don'tdoesn't get badly burnt It will be a wonder!

while we were in last trip theythere was a bad Auto accident
a machine and a party of 6 waswere coming from georgetown in the
Small hours of the morning and runran off the tresletrestle and turned
Completely over 1 killed and 4 Seriously Ingjured 3 of
them hashave died Since we CamCame away the driver is in Jail
that was my old CorseCourse but no more dear no more
for me! theythere was also a Street Car Accident at the fair grounds
1 killed and 50 wounded but none Seriously!
"On September 24, 1909, a Seattle Electric Company streetcar jumps the track at the corner of E 40th Street and 14th Avenue NE (later University Way). The streetcar crashes into three concession buildings across the street from the main entrance of the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. One passenger, Frank Hull of Tacoma, is killed, and 55 men, women, and children are injured" Stein. little
do we know how Soon we will be blotted out
of this world the best we Can do is to always be ready
I Suppose you have binbeen through most of themthe
letters by this time hasenthaven't, U.you and I wonder what you
think! yes I do—I wonder what u Uncle A thinks I wonder
Sometimes what I think! I Suppose you will be
getting ready for home in a Short time now! will you
be glad to get home honey I fink So! you have binbeen gone from
home quite a while haven't you? In another year you will be gone 2 months from here! that's the way the time
goes to me well honey I fink I had better singsign off I do
not want to take up all of your time—yes I do totoo—
but I must not be totoo Selfish Sisent nice! tell me dear
about writing or where to As you will be on your way
home before we finish another VoigeVoyage and tell me about
writing to your home (&tc) how I would like to see you
this A.M.morning So long honey

msContents.p: Letter from James J. McIntyre to Gladys telling how he missed a ship and how he has recently been telling his mother how much he appreciates all of Gladys's help.

div.p:
well I missed my boat this a.m. and cannot get away
untilluntil 1011 So I must write a few lines as promisepromised
how I would like to have had you with me last night
mother and I talked untilluntil 2 am Such a fine
talk we had and my little girl was the Subject honey
you Cannot emagineimagine how much She likes you when
I told her what you was doing for me how much
better I felt and how determined I was to do better
I told her about what you Said about what keen
was to Send me : well sometimes she was laughing and
Sometimes crying and dear if you could only have heard
what She Said about you well It could not please you
half as much as me I had to tell her all about you how
you comedcombed your hair about your eyes well and even
sing and dear you may hear from her to thank you I told
her about you praying for me and to be a little mean, I Said
I did not know if It was doing any good or not well
you ought to have herdheard what she said you cannot emagineimagine
how much she thinks of you and how good it makes me
feel honey deed it does : my sister was there and cons the

girl : Say honey She certanollycertainly Is a peach I missed my
boat as I told you before why I took them twoto their boat this a.m.
youghtyou ought to have Saw her In the Car her little arms a round
my neck all the time and when I kissed her good by she cried
like her little heart was broke and made me prommisepromise to come
over again : O dear how I would like you to know them
how proud I would be to heavehave the opportunity to take you to
them and I do hope I will have that please—Can I—
well dear I only have 35 min for the boat and have a little
way to go will write tomorrow and tell you the Steamboat news
this has binbeen nutter with a bum pen : you remeemberremember the
pen I got you at the Georgean well I would go farther
than that If I could have the opportunity again : well dear
So Long x

I remain "wif" heaps and then sum some
I would like to Say as I feel but Sesent nice It sis nice
I fink So long—yes— Sweet heart
